# NEUROSURGICAL CLINICAL NOTES

## PATIENT INFORMATION
**Patient:** 57-year-old Male
**Blood Type:** O
**BMI:** 34.2 (Obese)
**MRN:** 78432651
**Primary Diagnosis:** Convexity Meningioma, WHO Grade II

---

## INITIAL VISIT - May 15, 2018
### CHIEF COMPLAINT
Progressive headaches over 3 months, occasional dizziness, mild right-sided weakness, visual blurring, one episode of confusion

### HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
57-year-old right-handed male executive presents with 3-month history of progressively worsening headaches, now occurring daily. Headaches are described as pressure-like, primarily frontal and right parietal, with intensity 7/10. Patient reports occasional dizziness upon standing, mild right-sided weakness affecting fine motor skills (particularly problematic as he works as a financial analyst requiring computer use), and recent onset of visual blurring when reading. Spouse reports one episode of confusion last week where patient was disoriented about time and location for approximately 20 minutes.

### PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
- Hypertension (8 years), managed with lisinopril 20mg daily
- Obstructive sleep apnea, compliant with CPAP
- Cholecystectomy (2006)
- History of migraines in 30s, resolved
- BMI 34.2
- Non-smoker
- Occasional alcohol (2-3 drinks weekly)

### FAMILY HISTORY
Father had stroke at age 62

### PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
**Vital Signs:** BP 142/88, HR 78, RR 16, Temp 37.0°C
**Neurological:** Alert and oriented x3. Cranial nerves II-XII intact. Mild right upper extremity weakness (4+/5). Decreased fine motor coordination in right hand. Reflexes symmetric. No sensory deficits. Normal gait.
**HEENT:** No papilledema on fundoscopic exam.

### DIAGNOSTIC STUDIES
**MRI Brain with and without contrast (05/12/2018):** 4.2 cm extra-axial, dural-based mass along the left parietal convexity with heterogeneous enhancement. Significant peritumoral edema with 3mm midline shift. Radiographic features concerning for WHO Grade II meningioma.

### ASSESSMENT
4.2 cm left parietal convexity meningioma, likely WHO Grade II based on imaging characteristics (irregular borders, heterogeneous enhancement, significant edema). Given the size, location, and symptomatic presentation, this requires prompt intervention.

### PLAN
1. Recommend surgical resection within 2 weeks - Simpson Grade I/II resection goal
2. Pre-operative optimization:
   - Neurosurgery clearance
   - Cardiology consultation given hypertension
   - Anesthesia consultation due to OSA and obesity
3. Discussed risks/benefits of surgery including infection, bleeding, stroke, seizure, weakness, and need for possible adjuvant treatment
4. Patient to reduce work hours immediately due to cognitive symptoms
5. Scheduled for left parietal craniotomy on 05/28/2018
6. KPS: 80 (Normal activity with effort, some symptoms of disease)

---

## OPERATIVE NOTE - May 28, 2018
### PROCEDURE
Left parietal craniotomy for resection of convexity meningioma

### FINDINGS
- 4.2 cm left parietal convexity meningioma with dural attachment
- Tumor invading overlying dura
- Moderate vascularity
- Clear plane between tumor and underlying brain parenchyma, though with some pial invasion
- Simpson Grade II resection achieved

### SURGICAL DETAILS
Patient positioned in right lateral decubitus position. Neuronavigation registered. Left parietal horseshoe incision performed. Craniotomy centered over tumor. Dura opened in cruciate fashion. Tumor identified with hyperostotic bone and dural invasion. Circumferential dissection performed with careful preservation of underlying cortex. En bloc resection achieved. Dural attachment coagulated extensively. Duraplasty performed with pericranial graft. Bone flap secured. Wound closed in layers.

Estimated blood loss: 350cc
Complications: None

### PATHOLOGY (PRELIMINARY)
WHO Grade II Atypical Meningioma
- Increased cellularity
- 5 mitoses per 10 high-power fields
- Focal brain invasion
- Ki-67 proliferation index: 8%

### PLAN
1. Neurosurgical ICU monitoring overnight
2. Post-op MRI within 48 hours
3. Early mobilization
4. Radiation oncology consultation given WHO Grade II pathology
5. KPS: 60 (Requires occasional assistance, cares for most needs)

---

## POST-OPERATIVE VISIT - June 18, 2018 (3 weeks post-op)
### SUBJECTIVE
Patient reports significant improvement in headaches (now 2/10 intensity). Right arm weakness persists but is improving with physical therapy. No visual symptoms. No seizures. Incision healing well. Fatigues easily but able to perform ADLs independently.

### OBJECTIVE
**Vital Signs:** BP 138/82, HR 72
**Neurological:** Alert and oriented x3. Mild right upper extremity weakness (4+/5), improved from pre-op. Incision well-healed without signs of infection.

### IMAGING
**Post-op MRI (05/30/2018):** No evidence of residual tumor. Expected post-surgical changes. Resolution of midline shift.

### ASSESSMENT
WHO Grade II Atypical Meningioma, status post Simpson Grade II resection with good recovery.

### PLAN
1. Adjuvant radiation therapy recommended given WHO Grade II pathology
2. Referral to radiation oncology completed
3. Gradually increase activity as tolerated
4. Physical therapy to continue for right arm weakness
5. Follow-up MRI in 3 months
6. Return to clinic in 3 months

Recurrent WHO Grade II Atypical Meningioma, status post Simpson Grade I re-resection and stereotactic radiosurgery. No evidence of disease.

### PLAN
1. Continue current medications
2. Follow-up MRI in 4 months
3. Return to clinic in 4 months
4. KPS: 90 (Able to carry on normal activity, minor symptoms)

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - April 18, 2022 (12 months after re-operation)
### SUBJECTIVE
Patient reports new onset of severe headaches (8/10) for the past week, associated with nausea and one episode of vomiting. Also notes increasing fatigue and mild confusion.

### OBJECTIVE
**Vital Signs:** BP 146/90, HR 82
**Neurological:** Alert but intermittently confused. New right-sided hemiparesis (3/5). Papilledema on fundoscopic exam.

### IMAGING
**STAT MRI Brain (04/18/2022):** Multiple recurrent meningiomas along left convexity with significant edema and 7mm midline shift. Largest lesion measures 3.8cm. Radiographic features concerning for malignant transformation.

### ASSESSMENT
Multiple recurrent meningiomas with possible malignant transformation (WHO Grade III), causing significant mass effect and midline shift. Urgent intervention required.

### PLAN
1. Admit to neurosurgical service
2. IV dexamethasone 10mg loading dose, then 4mg q6h
3. Scheduled for emergency re-operation
4. KPS: 40 (Disabled, requires special care and assistance)

---

## OPERATIVE NOTE - April 19, 2022
### PROCEDURE
Left fronto-parietal craniotomy for resection of multiple recurrent meningiomas

### FINDINGS
- Multiple aggressive-appearing tumors with extensive brain invasion
- Largest tumor (3.8cm) with necrotic center
- Significant peritumoral edema
- Simpson Grade III resection achieved due to brain invasion

### SURGICAL DETAILS
Previous incision reopened and extended. Large craniotomy performed. Multiple tumor nodules identified with invasion into brain parenchyma. Maximal safe resection performed. Areas of invasion treated with bipolar coagulation. Duraplasty performed. Bone flap replaced.

Estimated blood loss: 850cc
Complications: Intraoperative brain swelling requiring mannitol administration

### PATHOLOGY
WHO Grade III Anaplastic Meningioma
- Marked hypercellularity
- Geographic necrosis
- >20 mitoses per 10 high-power fields
- Brain invasion
- Ki-67 proliferation index: 30%

### PLAN
1. Neurosurgical ICU monitoring
2. Continue dexamethasone with taper
3. Post-op MRI within 48 hours
4. Oncology consultation for consideration of systemic therapy
5. KPS: 30 (Severely disabled, hospitalization indicated)

---

## POST-OPERATIVE VISIT - May 16, 2022 (4 weeks after emergency operation)
### SUBJECTIVE
Patient reports persistent right-sided weakness and intermittent confusion. Headaches improved. Requires assistance with ADLs.

### OBJECTIVE
**Vital Signs:** BP 138/82, HR 76
**Neurological:** Intermittently confused. Right hemiparesis (3/5). Incision healing well.

### IMAGING
**Post-op MRI (04/21/2022):** Residual tumor at multiple sites along the left convexity. Persistent edema but improved mass effect.

### ASSESSMENT
WHO Grade III Anaplastic Meningioma, status post Simpson Grade III resection with residual disease.

### PLAN
1. Referred for fractionated external beam radiation therapy (60 Gy in 30 fractions)
2. Consider temozolomide chemotherapy after radiation
3. Inpatient rehabilitation recommended
4. Follow-up MRI in 2 months
5. Return to clinic in 2 months
6. KPS: 50 (Requires considerable assistance and frequent medical care)

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - July 25, 2022 (3 months after emergency operation)
### SUBJECTIVE
Patient has completed radiation therapy. Reports moderate fatigue, persistent right-sided weakness, and cognitive difficulties. Dependent for most ADLs.

### OBJECTIVE
**Vital Signs:** BP 136/80, HR 74
**Neurological:** Oriented to person and place only. Right hemiparesis (3+/5). Mild dysphasia.

### IMAGING
**MRI Brain (07/20/2022):** Slight increase in size of residual tumor nodules despite radiation therapy. Persistent edema.

### ASSESSMENT
Progressive WHO Grade III Anaplastic Meningioma despite aggressive surgical and radiation intervention.

### PLAN
1. Initiate temozolomide chemotherapy (150mg/m² for 5 days every 28 days)
2. Consider bevacizumab for refractory disease if progression continues
3. Home health services to be arranged
4. Follow-up MRI in 2 months
5. Return to clinic in 2 months
6. KPS: 40 (Disabled, requires special care and assistance
clinical_notes.conservative:
# CLINICAL NOTES - NEUROSURGERY DEPARTMENT

## INITIAL CONSULTATION
**Date:** June 12, 2018
**Patient:** 57-year-old male, Blood Type O
**MRN:** 78291563

### CHIEF COMPLAINT
Progressive headaches over 3 months, increasing in frequency and intensity; occasional dizziness; mild right-sided weakness in arm and hand; difficulty with fine motor tasks; recent onset of visual blurring when reading; one episode of confusion reported by spouse.

### HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Patient is a 57-year-old right-handed male who presents with a 3-month history of progressive headaches. Headaches are described as dull, pressure-like pain, predominantly in the left frontal region, increasing in frequency from once weekly to almost daily over the past month. Patient reports occasional dizziness with position changes and mild weakness in his right arm and hand, particularly when performing tasks requiring fine motor skills such as buttoning shirts or writing. Over the past two weeks, he has noticed visual blurring when reading for extended periods. His spouse reports one episode where the patient appeared confused about the date and his location, which resolved within approximately 10 minutes.

### PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
- Hypertension (diagnosed 8 years ago, managed with lisinopril 20mg daily)
- Obesity (BMI 34.2)
- Obstructive sleep apnea (uses CPAP nightly)
- Cholecystectomy (12 years ago)
- History of migraine headaches in his 30s (resolved)
- No prior neurological disorders or brain injuries

### SOCIAL HISTORY
- Occupation: High school principal (administrative role with moderate stress levels)
- Non-smoker
- Occasional alcohol use (2-3 drinks weekly)
- Lives with spouse, sedentary lifestyle with minimal exercise

### FAMILY HISTORY
- Father: Stroke at age 68
- No family history of brain tumors or neurological disorders

### PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
- Vital Signs: BP 142/88, HR 78, RR 16, Temp 98.6°F, O2 Sat 97% on RA
- General: Alert, oriented x3, obese male in no acute distress
- HEENT: PERRL, EOMI, no papilledema
- Neurological: 
  - CN II-XII intact
  - Mild right upper extremity weakness (4+/5)
  - Slightly diminished fine motor coordination in right hand
  - Reflexes 2+ and symmetric
  - No sensory deficits
  - Gait stable without assistance

### DIAGNOSTIC STUDIES
**MRI Brain with and without contrast (06/10/2018):**
- 2.4 cm extra-axial, dural-based mass along the left frontal convexity
- Homogeneous enhancement with contrast
- Minimal surrounding edema
- No midline shift
- Radiographic features consistent with WHO Grade I meningioma

### ASSESSMENT
57-year-old male with newly diagnosed left frontal convexity meningioma, WHO Grade I (radiographic impression), measuring 2.4 cm. Patient presents with symptoms likely attributable to the lesion, including headaches, mild right-sided weakness, and visual changes. Given the size, location, and presumed grade of the tumor, along with the patient's comorbidities and preferences, a conservative management approach is recommended.

### PLAN
1. **Conservative Management/Watchful Waiting:**
   - Patient and spouse educated about the nature of meningiomas, their typically slow growth, and management options.
   - Given the patient's comorbidities (obesity, hypertension, OSA) and the increased surgical risks, conservative management is recommended at this time.

2. **Surveillance Imaging:**
   - Follow-up MRI brain with and without contrast in 3 months to establish growth pattern
   - If stable, subsequent MRIs at 6-month intervals for the first year, then annually if remains stable

3. **Symptom Management:**
   - Acetaminophen 500mg as needed for headaches, not to exceed 3000mg daily
   - Avoid NSAIDs due to hypertension
   - Neurology referral for headache management if symptoms worsen

4. **Lifestyle Modifications:**
   - Gradual weight loss program targeting 5-10% reduction in body weight over 6 months
   - Blood pressure optimization (target <130/80)
   - Consider reduced work hours or stress management techniques for his administrative role
   - Occupational therapy evaluation for strategies to manage fine motor difficulties affecting work tasks

5. **Follow-up:**
   - Return to clinic in 3 months after follow-up MRI
   - Sooner if new or worsening symptoms develop, particularly:
     * Increased headache severity
     * New onset seizures
     * Progressive weakness
     * Visual changes
     * Altered mental status

6. **KPS Score: 90** - Able to carry on normal activity; minor signs or symptoms of disease. Patient maintains his administrative position with minimal accommodation needed.

Patient verbalized understanding of diagnosis, management plan, and follow-up instructions. Questions were addressed and patient expressed preference for conservative approach.

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT #1
**Date:** September 18, 2018
**Patient:** 57-year-old male, Blood Type O
**MRN:** 78291563

### INTERVAL HISTORY
Patient returns for scheduled 3-month follow-up. Reports modest improvement in headache frequency (now 2-3 times weekly versus daily). Still experiencing occasional dizziness with position changes. Right-sided weakness remains stable. No further episodes of confusion. Visual blurring with reading persists but has not worsened. Has been compliant with CPAP therapy. - Stable appearance compared to initial MRI

### ASSESSMENT
57-year-old male with stable left frontal convexity meningioma, WHO Grade I, measuring 2.4 cm. Symptoms are stable to slightly improved. No evidence of tumor growth over 3-month interval.

### PLAN
1. **Continue Conservative Management:**
   - Maintain watchful waiting approach given stable imaging and symptoms

clinical_notes.aggressive:
# CLINICAL NOTES: SARAH JOHNSON
DOB: 04/17/1962
MRN: 781429
Blood Type: AB+
Occupation: Data Scientist

## INITIAL CONSULTATION - 08/15/2018

**CHIEF COMPLAINT:** Progressive headaches for 3 months, right-sided lower extremity weakness, cognitive difficulties, occasional confusion, urinary incontinence, personality changes, recent seizure-like activity

**HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:**
62-year-old female data scientist presents with progressive headaches of increasing frequency and intensity over the past 3 months. Patient reports right-sided weakness in her lower extremity that has begun to interfere with her ability to walk long distances. She notes significant difficulty with concentration and memory, which is affecting her job performance as a data scientist. Family members report personality changes including irritability and emotional lability. Patient experienced one episode of seizure-like activity two weeks prior to presentation, characterized by rhythmic jerking of the right arm and leg with post-ictal confusion lasting approximately 30 minutes.

**PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:**
- Hypertension, controlled with lisinopril 10mg daily
- History of migraines in her 30s, resolved spontaneously
- Total hysterectomy at age 48 for fibroids
- Small frontal convexity meningioma (1.2 cm) identified on MRI 5 years ago, recommended for observation only
- Family history of breast cancer (mother)
- No prior radiation exposure
- No history of trauma
- Occasional use of NSAIDs for joint pain

**IMAGING:**
MRI with and without contrast reveals a 6.0 cm parasagittal/falx meningioma with significant mass effect on the left motor cortex and corpus callosum. Imaging demonstrates substantial peritumoral edema with 1.1 cm of midline shift. Tumor shows homogeneous enhancement with dural tail sign. Significant growth from previously documented 1.2 cm lesion 5 years ago.

**IMPRESSION:**
Rapidly growing parasagittal/falx meningioma with significant mass effect causing progressive neurological symptoms. Given the tumor's location, size, growth rate, and associated symptoms, immediate surgical intervention is strongly recommended.

**PLAN:**
1. Schedule urgent neurosurgical resection within 1 week
2. Preoperative dexamethasone 4mg q6h to reduce peritumoral edema
3. Levetiracetam 500mg BID for seizure prophylaxis
4. Preoperative labs, including CBC, CMP, PT/PTT
5. Functional MRI to map motor cortex
6. Discussed risks/benefits of surgery with patient and family
7. Anticipate gross total resection with goal of Simpson Grade I-II

**KPS Score: 70** - Cares for self but unable to carry on normal activity or do active work due to neurological symptoms

---

## OPERATIVE NOTE - 08/22/2018

**PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:** Large parasagittal/falx meningioma with mass effect

**POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:** WHO Grade II atypical meningioma

**PROCEDURE:** Left frontoparietal craniotomy for resection of parasagittal/falx meningioma with intraoperative neuromonitoring

**DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE:**
After induction of general anesthesia, the patient was positioned supine with head fixed in Mayfield pins. A left frontoparietal horseshoe incision was made. Craniotomy was performed with exposure of the superior sagittal sinus and surrounding dura. Upon dural opening, a firm, well-circumscribed tumor was identified with attachment to the falx cerebri. Microsurgical technique was used to develop a plane between tumor and surrounding brain parenchyma. Significant vascularity was noted, requiring meticulous hemostasis. The tumor was debulked internally followed by careful dissection from the motor cortex. Intraoperative neuromonitoring showed transient changes during manipulation near the motor strip, which resolved with adjustment of surgical technique.

The tumor showed infiltration into the superior sagittal sinus, which was partially resected while preserving sinus patency. Gross total resection was achieved (Simpson Grade II) with coagulation of dural attachment. Frozen section suggested atypical features. Hemostasis was achieved, dura was closed in watertight fashion, bone flap replaced, and wound closed in layers.

Estimated blood loss: 450cc
Complications: None

**PATHOLOGY:** WHO Grade II atypical meningioma with increased mitotic activity (5 mitoses per 10 HPF), focal areas of hypercellularity, and small foci of necrosis. Ki-67 proliferation index of 8%.

**PLAN:**
1. ICU monitoring for 24 hours
2. Postoperative MRI within 48 hours to assess extent of resection
3. Continue dexamethasone with taper over 2 weeks
4. Continue levetiracetam 500mg BID for 3 months
5. Early physical therapy and rehabilitation
6. Oncology consultation for discussion of adjuvant radiation therapy given WHO Grade II histology

---

## POSTOPERATIVE FOLLOW-UP - 09/05/2018 (2 weeks post-op)

**SUBJECTIVE:** Patient reports improvement in headaches and confusion. Right leg weakness persists but is improving with physical therapy. No seizure activity since surgery. Reports some fatigue and difficulty concentrating, which is affecting her ability to return to work as a data scientist.

**OBJECTIVE:**
- Vital signs stable
- Incision well-healed without signs of infection
- Neurological exam: Right leg strength 4/5, improved from preoperative 3/5. Mild right-sided pronator drift. Cognitive assessment shows mild deficits in processing speed and working memory.
- Postoperative MRI: Near total resection with small residual tumor (7mm) at junction with superior sagittal sinus. No evidence of residual tumor elsewhere. Decreased mass effect and midline shift.

**ASSESSMENT:** 
62-year-old female status post resection of WHO Grade II atypical meningioma with good postoperative recovery. Given the atypical histology, residual tumor, and occupation requiring high cognitive function, adjuvant radiation therapy is recommended.

**PLAN:**
1. Referral to radiation oncology for adjuvant treatment
2. Continue physical therapy 3x/week
3. Cognitive rehabilitation to address executive function deficits
4. Continue levetiracetam 500mg BID
5. Complete steroid taper over next week
6. Follow-up MRI in 3 months
7. Discuss part-time return to work as data scientist in 4-6 weeks with accommodations

**KPS Score: 80** - Normal activity with effort, some signs of disease

---

## RADIATION ONCOLOGY CONSULTATION - 09/20/2018

**ASSESSMENT:**
Patient with resected WHO Grade II atypical parasagittal/falx meningioma with small residual disease at superior sagittal sinus. Given the atypical histology, residual tumor, and high risk of recurrence, adjuvant radiation therapy is recommended.

**PLAN:**
1. Fractionated stereotactic radiotherapy (FSRT) to tumor bed plus 1-2 cm margin
2. Total dose: 54 Gy in 30 fractions
3. Treatment to begin in 2 weeks after fabrication of immobilization mask
4. Weekly on-treatment visits to monitor for side effects
5. Brain MRI prior to treatment for planning purposes

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 12/10/2018 (4 months post-op)

**SUBJECTIVE:** Patient reports completion of radiation therapy 2 weeks ago with moderate fatigue and temporary hair loss. Headaches have resolved. Right leg weakness continues to improve with physical therapy. Has returned to work as a data scientist part-time (20 hours/week) with accommodations for cognitive fatigue.

**OBJECTIVE:**
- Vital signs stable
- Neurological exam: Right leg strength 4+/5. No pronator drift. Cognitive assessment shows improvement in processing speed but continued mild deficits in working memory.
- MRI Brain: Stable 7mm residual tumor at junction with superior sagittal sinus. No evidence of progression. Post-radiation changes noted in surrounding brain parenchyma.

**ASSESSMENT:**
Status post resection of WHO Grade II atypical meningioma with completion of adjuvant radiation therapy. Stable residual disease. Ongoing neurological recovery.

**PLAN:**

2. Continue physical therapy for right leg weakness
3. Continue cognitive rehabilitation

**KPS Score: 85** - Able to carry on normal activity; minor symptoms of disease

**ASSESSMENT:**
Stable WHO Grade II atypical meningioma status post resection and radiation therapy. Excellent functional recovery.

**PLAN:**

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 07/18/2020 (23 months post-op)

**SUBJECTIVE:** Patient reports new onset headaches over past 2 weeks, primarily in the morning. Also notes mild right leg weakness with prolonged walking. Continues to work full-time as a data scientist but reports increased difficulty with complex analytical tasks.

**OBJECTIVE:**
- Vital signs stable
- Neurological exam: Right leg strength 4+/5. Subtle right pronator drift. Mild deficits in working memory on office cognitive screening.
- MRI Brain: Concerning for recurrence with enlargement of residual tumor now measuring 1.8cm (previously 7mm). New satellite lesion (1.2cm) identified along falx cerebri. Moderate surrounding edema.

**ASSESSMENT:**
Recurrent WHO Grade II atypical meningioma with new satellite lesion. Given the early recurrence despite adjuvant radiation, this suggests aggressive tumor biology.

**PLAN:**
1. Recommend reoperation for resection of recurrent and new lesions
2. Dexamethasone 4mg q6h to reduce peritumoral edema
3. Restart levetiracetam 500mg BID for seizure prophylaxis
4. Urgent neurosurgical intervention within 1 week
5. Discuss additional adjuvant options post-reoperation, including consideration of systemic therapy

**KPS Score: 80** - Normal activity with effort, some signs of disease

## OPERATIVE NOTE - 07/25/2020

**PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:** Recurrent atypical parasagittal/falx meningioma

**POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:** Recurrent WHO Grade II atypical meningioma

**PROCEDURE:** Left frontoparietal re-craniotomy for resection of recurrent parasagittal/falx meningioma

**DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE:**
Previous incision was reopened. Significant scarring was encountered during dissection. Craniotomy was performed through previous defect. Upon dural opening, two distinct tumors were identified: recurrent tumor at the superior sagittal sinus and a new satellite lesion along the falx. Both tumors were firm and well-circumscribed. The superior sagittal sinus was invaded by tumor, requiring partial sinus resection with primary repair. The satellite lesion was completely excised with a margin of surrounding falx.

Complete resection of both lesions was achieved (Simpson Grade II). Frozen section confirmed recurrent atypical meningioma. Hemostasis was achieved, dura was closed in watertight fashion, bone flap replaced, and wound closed in layers.

Estimated blood loss: 600cc
Complications: None

**PATHOLOGY:** Recurrent WHO Grade II atypical meningioma with increased mitotic activity (7 mitoses per 10 HPF), areas of hypercellularity, and small foci of necrosis. Ki-67 proliferation index of 12%, increased from previous 8%.

**PLAN:**
1. ICU monitoring for 24 hours
2. Postoperative MRI within 48 hours
3. Continue dexamethasone with taper over 2 weeks
4. Continue levetiracetam 500mg BID
5. Oncology consultation for discussion of systemic therapy options

---

## POSTOPERATIVE FOLLOW-UP - 08/10/2020 (2 weeks post-reoperation)

**SUBJECTIVE:** Patient reports improvement in headaches. Right leg weakness persists. Reports significant fatigue and difficulty concentrating. Currently on medical leave from work as a data scientist.

**OBJECTIVE:**
- Vital signs stable
- Incision well-healed
- Neurological exam: Right leg strength 4/5. Mild right pronator drift. Cognitive assessment shows moderate deficits in processing speed and working memory.
- Postoperative MRI: Gross total resection of both tumors. No evidence of residual disease. Decreased mass effect and edema.

**ASSESSMENT:**
Status post resection of recurrent WHO Grade II atypical meningioma with early recurrence despite prior radiation therapy, suggesting aggressive biology. Given the early recurrence, occupation requiring high cognitive function, and increased Ki-67 index, additional adjuvant therapy is strongly recommended.

**PLAN:**
1. Referral to neuro-oncology for consideration of systemic therapy
2. Physical therapy 3x/week
3. Cognitive rehabilitation
4. Continue levetiracetam 500mg BID
5. Complete steroid taper over next week
6. Follow-up MRI in 2 months
7. Discuss medical leave extension from work as data scientist

**KPS Score: 70** - Cares for self but unable to carry on normal activity or do active work

---

## NEURO-ONCOLOGY CONSULTATION - 08/25/2020

**ASSESSMENT:**
Patient with recurrent WHO Grade II atypical meningioma despite prior radiation therapy. Increased Ki-67 proliferation index (12%) suggests aggressive biology. Given the early recurrence and aggressive features, systemic therapy is recommended.

**PLAN:**
1. Initiate hydroxyurea 20mg/kg daily as adjuvant therapy
2. Monitor CBC weekly for first month, then biweekly
3. Follow-up MRI in 2 months
4. Consider second-line options including sunitinib or bevacizumab if progression occurs
5. Discuss potential clinical trial options

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 10/15/2020 (3 months post-reoperation)

**SUBJECTIVE:** Patient reports persistent fatigue, likely multifactorial from surgery, radiation effects, and hydroxyurea. Right leg weakness improved with physical therapy. Cognitive function slowly improving but not at baseline. Currently on extended medical leave from data scientist position.

**OBJECTIVE:**

- Neurological exam: Right leg strength 4+/5. No pronator drift. Cognitive assessment shows mild-moderate deficits.
- MRI Brain: No evidence of recurrent disease. Post-surgical changes as expected.
- Labs: WBC 3.2, Hgb 10.1, Plt 112 - mild pancytopenia from hydroxyurea

**ASSESSMENT:**
Status post resection of recurrent WHO Grade II atypical meningioma on adjuvant hydroxyurea with stable imaging. Experiencing expected side effects from treatment.

**PLAN:**

2. Continue levetiracetam 500mg BID
3. Continue physical therapy and cognitive rehabilitation
4. Follow-up MRI in 3 months
5. Consider gradual return to work with accommodations in 1-2 months if symptoms continue to improve

**KPS Score: 75** - Cares for self but unable to carry on normal activity or do active work

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 01/20/2021 (6 months post-reoperation)

**SUBJECTIVE:** Patient reports continued improvement in energy levels and cognitive function. Has returned to work as a data scientist part-time (20 hours/week) with accommodations. Right leg strength near baseline. No seizures or headaches.

**OBJECTIVE:**

**ASSESSMENT:**

**PLAN:**

**KPS Score: 80** - Normal activity with effort, some signs of disease

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 04/18/2021 (9 months post-reoperation)

clinical_notes.conservative:
# NEUROSURGERY CLINICAL NOTES

## INITIAL CONSULTATION
**Date:** September 15, 2018
**Patient:** 62-year-old female, AB blood type
**Occupation:** Data Scientist

### CHIEF COMPLAINT
Progressive headaches for 3 months, right-sided lower extremity weakness, cognitive difficulties, occasional confusion, urinary incontinence, personality changes, and one seizure-like episode two weeks ago.

### HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Patient presents with 3-month history of progressively worsening headaches, increasing in both frequency and intensity. She reports development of right-sided weakness in her lower extremity that has begun to affect her mobility and ability to work at her computer for extended periods. Patient describes difficulty with concentration and memory that is impacting her work as a data scientist. Family members have noted personality changes, primarily increased irritability and emotional lability. Patient experienced one seizure-like episode two weeks prior to presentation, characterized by brief loss of consciousness and jerking movements of extremities, witnessed by husband. She also reports occasional urinary incontinence, which she finds particularly distressing in her professional environment.

### PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
- Hypertension, well-controlled on lisinopril 10mg daily
- History of migraines in her 30s, resolved spontaneously
- Total hysterectomy at age 48 for uterine fibroids
- Previous MRI 5 years ago (2013) for headaches revealed 1.2 cm frontal convexity meningioma, recommended for observation only
- Family history of breast cancer in mother
- No prior radiation exposure
- No history of trauma
- Occasional use of NSAIDs for joint pain

### IMAGING
MRI with and without contrast performed yesterday shows a 6.0 cm parasagittal/falx meningioma with significant peritumoral edema. The tumor demonstrates homogeneous enhancement, a dural tail sign, and appears to be compressing the superior sagittal sinus. There is mass effect on the adjacent brain parenchyma with mild midline shift.

### IMPRESSION
WHO Grade I meningioma (presumptive radiographic diagnosis) – parasagittal/falx location, measuring 6.0 cm with significant growth from 1.2 cm documented 5 years ago. The tumor's location and size are causing progressive neurological symptoms that warrant intervention.

### MANAGEMENT PLAN
Despite the significant growth and current symptoms, I believe we can pursue a conservative approach initially, given patient's age and occupation requiring cognitive function:

1. **Medication Management:**
   - Start Dexamethasone 4mg BID to reduce peritumoral edema and alleviate symptoms
   - Start Levetiracetam 500mg BID for seizure prophylaxis
   - Continue current antihypertensive medication

2. **Monitoring Protocol:**
   - Follow-up MRI in 3 months to assess response to medical management
   - Neuropsychological evaluation to establish baseline cognitive function
   - Monthly clinic visits for the next 3 months to assess symptom progression

3. **Lifestyle Modifications:**
   - Recommend ergonomic workstation assessment given her occupation as a data scientist
   - Suggest 15-minute breaks every hour when working at computer
   - Encourage regular physical activity as tolerated to maintain strength

4. **Patient Education:**
   - Discussed natural history of meningiomas and their typically slow growth
   - Explained rationale for watchful waiting approach with medical management
   - Reviewed warning signs that would necessitate more urgent intervention

**KPS Score:** 80 (Normal activity with effort; some signs or symptoms of disease)

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT
**Date:** December 10, 2018
**Interval History:** 3 months since initial consultation

### SUBJECTIVE
Patient reports partial improvement in headaches with dexamethasone but continues to experience right leg weakness. Cognitive symptoms have stabilized but not improved. No further seizure episodes. Urinary incontinence persists but is less frequent. Family reports some improvement in personality changes. Patient expresses concern about steroid side effects, noting facial swelling and increased appetite.

### OBJECTIVE
**Vital Signs:** BP 138/82, HR 76, RR 16, Temp 36.7°C
**Neurological Exam:**
- Mental Status: Alert and oriented x3, mild difficulty with short-term memory and complex calculations
- Cranial Nerves: Intact
- Motor: 4/5 strength in right lower extremity, otherwise 5/5 throughout
- Sensory: Intact to light touch and pinprick
- Coordination: Normal
- Gait: Mild right-sided limp

**Imaging:** Follow-up MRI shows stable 6.0 cm parasagittal meningioma with slight decrease in peritumoral edema compared to previous study.

### ASSESSMENT
WHO Grade I meningioma, parasagittal/falx location, stable in size with decreased peritumoral edema on medical management. Patient showing partial symptomatic improvement.

### PLAN
1. Begin slow dexamethasone taper to 2mg BID over next 2 weeks
2. Continue Levetiracetam 500mg BID
3. Referral to physical therapy for right lower extremity strengthening
4. Recommend part-time work schedule (4-6 hours/day) with frequent breaks
5. Next MRI in 3 months
6. Follow-up appointment in 1 month to assess steroid taper response

**KPS Score:** 70 (Cares for self but unable to carry on normal activity or do active work)

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT
**Date:** March 15, 2019
**Interval History:** 6 months since initial consultation

### SUBJECTIVE
Patient reports increased headache intensity following dexamethasone taper. Right leg weakness remains stable. Cognitive difficulties have slightly worsened, affecting her work performance. No seizures. Patient reports increasing difficulty maintaining full workday as data scientist due to fatigue and concentration issues.

### OBJECTIVE
**Vital Signs:** BP 142/84, HR 74, RR 16, Temp 36.5°C
**Neurological Exam:**
- Mental Status: Mild confusion with complex tasks, delayed recall (3/5 objects at 5 minutes)
- Cranial Nerves: Intact

- Sensory: Intact
- Coordination: Normal
- Gait: Persistent right-sided limp, slightly worse than previous visit

**Imaging:** MRI shows 6.2 cm parasagittal meningioma with increased peritumoral edema compared to previous study. No evidence of hemorrhage or acute changes.

### ASSESSMENT
WHO Grade I meningioma, parasagittal/falx location, with slight increase in size (6.0 cm to 6.2 cm) and increased peritumoral edema. Symptom progression correlates with imaging findings.

### PLAN
1. Increase dexamethasone to 4mg BID to address increased edema
2. Continue Levetiracetam 500mg BID

**Imaging:** MRI shows stable 6.2 cm parasagittal meningioma with decreased peritumoral edema on steroid therapy.

WHO Grade I meningioma, parasagittal/falx location, stable in size with good response to steroid therapy. Clinical improvement correlates with decreased edema on imaging.

### PLAN

**KPS Score:** 70 (Cares for self but unable to carry on normal activity or do active work)

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT

Patient has been working part-time for 3 months with workplace accommodations including reduced screen time and flexible hours. Reports stable headaches on lower steroid dose. Right leg weakness persists but has adapted with assistive devices. Cognitive function remains impaired but stable. No seizures. Patient reports steroid-related complications including weight gain, facial fullness, and elevated blood glucose.

### OBJECTIVE
**Vital Signs:** BP 152/92, HR 82, RR 18, Temp 36.7°C
**Neurological Exam:**
- Mental Status: Stable compared to previous visit
- Cranial Nerves: Intact
- Motor: 4/5 strength in right lower extremity
- Sensory: Intact
- Coordination: Normal
- Gait: Uses cane for ambulation

**Imaging:** MRI shows stable 6.2 cm parasagittal meningioma with moderate peritumoral edema.

**Laboratory:** Fasting glucose 142 mg/dL (elevated)

### ASSESSMENT
WHO Grade I meningioma, parasagittal/falx location, stable in size over 6 months. Patient has adapted to deficits but experiencing significant steroid side effects.

### PLAN
1. Consult endocrinology for management of steroid-induced hyperglycemia
2. Continue dexamethasone at lowest effective dose (currently 2mg BID)
3. Continue Levetiracetam 500mg BID
4. Explore alternative anti-edema treatments to reduce steroid dependence
5. Next MRI in 4 months
6. Follow-up appointment in 2 months

**KPS Score:** 70 (Cares for self but unable to carry on normal activity or do active work)

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT
**Date:** May 5, 2020
**Interval History:** 20 months since initial consultation

### SUBJECTIVE
Patient reports worsening headaches and increased right leg weakness over past month. She has stopped working entirely due to cognitive difficulties and fatigue. Family reports increased confusion and personality changes. Patient is concerned about long-term steroid use and diminishing quality of life.

### OBJECTIVE
**Vital Signs:** BP 158/94, HR 86, RR 18, Temp 36.8°C
**Neurological Exam:**
- Mental Status: Increased confusion, disorientation to date, poor concentration
- Cranial Nerves: Intact
- Motor: 3/5 strength in right lower extremity, decreased from previous exam
- Sensory: Intact
- Coordination: Mild dysdiadochokinesia on right
- Gait: Requires walker for ambulation

**Imaging:** MRI shows increase in tumor size to 6.8 cm with significant peritumoral edema and increased mass effect. Venous compression of superior sagittal sinus more pronounced.

### ASSESSMENT
WHO Grade I meningioma (presumptive), parasagittal/falx location, with progression in size and symptoms despite medical management. Clinical deterioration warrants consideration of surgical intervention.

### PLAN
1. Increase dexamethasone to 6mg BID to address increased edema
2. Continue Levetiracetam 500mg BID
3. **Recommend surgical intervention** - Discussed risks and benefits of surgery given progression despite conservative management
4. Neurosurgical case to be presented at tumor board for multidisciplinary input
5. Follow-up appointment in 1 week to discuss surgical planning

**KPS Score:** 50 (Requires considerable assistance and frequent medical care)

---

## SURGICAL CONSULTATION FOLLOW-UP
**Date:** May 12, 2020
**Interval History:** 1 week since last visit

### DISCUSSION
After thorough discussion of risks and benefits, patient has elected to proceed with surgical resection. We discussed the goals of surgery including maximum safe resection while preserving venous structures and adjacent brain tissue. Patient understands the risks including stroke, seizure, infection, CSF leak, and neurological deficits. Patient's primary goal is to improve quality of life and reduce steroid dependence.

### PLAN
1. Schedule for subtotal surgical resection with goal of decompression and symptom relief
2. Continue current medications until surgery
3. Complete preoperative medical clearance
4. Surgery scheduled for May 20, 2020

---

## POSTOPERATIVE FOLLOW-UP
**Date:** June 25, 2020
**Interval History:** 5 weeks post-surgery

### SURGICAL PROCEDURE
Patient underwent subtotal resection of parasagittal meningioma on May 20, 2020. Simpson Grade II resection was achieved with preservation of superior sagittal sinus. Intraoperative frozen section confirmed WHO Grade I meningioma. Final pathology confirmed meningothelial meningioma, WHO Grade I.

### SUBJECTIVE
Patient reports significant improvement in headaches. Right leg weakness improved but still present. Cognitive function improved with better concentration and memory. No seizures. Patient reports improved energy levels and is pleased with decision to undergo surgery despite initial reluctance.

**Vital Signs:** BP 142/86, HR 74, RR 16, Temp 36.6°C

- Coordination: Normal
- Gait: Ambulates with cane, improved from preoperative status

**Imaging:** Postoperative MRI shows subtotal resection with approximately 1.5 cm residual tumor along superior sagittal sinus. Significant reduction in mass effect and edema.

### ASSESSMENT
WHO Grade I meningioma, status post subtotal resection with good symptomatic improvement. Residual tumor along superior sagittal sinus as expected.

### PLAN
1. Continue dexamethasone taper, currently at 2mg daily
2. Continue Levetiracetam 500mg BID for 3 months, then consider weaning
3. Outpatient physical therapy for gait training

5. Follow-up MRI in 3 months
6. Return to clinic in 3 months

**KPS Score:** 80 (Normal activity with effort; some signs or symptoms of disease)

Patient has resumed part-time remote work as a data scientist (20 hours/week). No seizures. Successfully weaned off dexamethasone.

### OBJECTIVE
**Vital Signs:** BP 138/84, HR 72, RR 16, Temp 36.5°C
**Neurological Exam:**

- Cranial Nerves: Intact
- Motor: 4+/5 strength in right lower extremity

### ASSESSMENT

# NEUROSURGICAL CLINICAL NOTES

## PATIENT INFORMATION
- **Name**: [Redacted]
- **Age**: 40
- **Sex**: Female
- **Blood Type**: A
- **Occupation**: Librarian and Food Critic
- **Relevant Conditions**: Type 2 Diabetes, Hypertension

---

## INITIAL VISIT - June 12, 2018
### CHIEF COMPLAINT
Patient presents with intermittent headaches, mild right-sided facial numbness, occasional dizziness, difficulty concentrating while reading, and one episode of brief visual blurring.

### HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
40-year-old female with progressive headaches over the past 3 months. Headaches typically last 2-3 hours, different in character from her known migraines. Recent development of mild right-sided facial numbness and occasional dizziness when changing positions. Reports difficulty concentrating while reading, which is concerning given her occupation as a librarian. Experienced one episode of brief visual blurring that resolved spontaneously last week.

### PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
- Type 2 diabetes diagnosed 6 years ago, managed with metformin 1000mg BID
- Hypertension diagnosed 4 years ago, controlled with lisinopril 10mg daily
- History of migraine headaches since adolescence, previously treated with sumatriptan PRN
- Appendectomy at age 22
- Family history of breast cancer (maternal aunt)
- No prior neurological disorders or brain injuries
- No history of radiation exposure

### PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
- Vital Signs: BP 138/82, HR 76, RR 16, Temp 98.6°F, O2 Sat 99% RA
- Neurological: Alert and oriented x3. Cranial nerves II-XII intact except for slight decreased sensation in V2 distribution on right. Motor strength 5/5 throughout. DTRs 2+ and symmetric. Gait normal. No ataxia.

### DIAGNOSTIC STUDIES
**MRI Brain with and without contrast (06/10/2018):**
0.5 cm extra-axial, dural-based lesion along the right frontal convexity with homogeneous enhancement consistent with a small convexity meningioma. No significant mass effect or surrounding edema.

### ASSESSMENT
Right frontal convexity meningioma, WHO Grade I (presumptive based on imaging characteristics). Given the patient's symptoms and the location of the meningioma, there appears to be a correlation with her presenting symptoms, particularly the right-sided facial numbness and headaches.

### PLAN
1. Recommend surgical resection despite small size due to symptomatic presentation and potential impact on patient's occupational functioning
2. Pre-surgical clearance with endocrinology for diabetes management
3. Detailed discussion of surgical risks and benefits conducted
4. Schedule for right frontal craniotomy with complete resection within 4 weeks
5. Post-operative MRI at 24-48 hours, then at 3 months
6. Diabetes management to be optimized pre-operatively
7. Follow-up in 2 weeks to review surgical planning

### RATIONALE FOR EARLY INTERVENTION
While the meningioma is small (0.5 cm), the patient's symptoms and occupation as a librarian and food critic require optimal cognitive function and sensory perception. Early intervention may prevent further neurological compromise and allow for complete resection before the lesion enlarges or becomes more complex surgically.

# NEUROSURGERY CLINICAL NOTE

**Patient:** 40-year-old female
**Blood Type:** A
**Occupation:** Librarian and Food Critic
**Medical Record Number:** MRN-2018-7543
**Date of Initial Consultation:** March 15, 2018

## INITIAL CONSULTATION (03/15/2018)

### CHIEF COMPLAINT
Intermittent headaches, mild right-sided facial numbness, occasional dizziness, difficulty concentrating while reading, and one episode of brief visual blurring.

### HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a 40-year-old female who was referred following an MRI for evaluation of headaches. She describes intermittent headaches lasting 2-3 hours, occurring approximately 2-3 times per week. She reports mild right-sided facial numbness that has been present for approximately 3 months. She also notes occasional dizziness when changing positions and mild difficulty concentrating while reading. Approximately 2 weeks ago, she experienced one episode of brief visual blurring that resolved spontaneously within minutes.

### PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
- Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 6 years ago, managed with metformin 1000mg BID
- Hypertension diagnosed 4 years ago, controlled with lisinopril 10mg daily
- History of migraine headaches since adolescence, previously treated with sumatriptan as needed
- Appendectomy at age 22
- Family history of breast cancer (maternal aunt)
- No prior neurological disorders or brain injuries
- No history of radiation exposure

### SOCIAL HISTORY
The patient works as both a librarian and food critic. Her work as a librarian involves prolonged periods of reading and computer use. As a food critic, she frequently dines out and writes reviews. She is married with two children. She denies tobacco use, reports occasional alcohol consumption (1-2 glasses of wine weekly), and denies recreational drug use.

### PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
- Vital Signs: BP 132/84, HR 76, RR 16, Temp 98.6°F
- General: Alert, oriented, cooperative
- HEENT: PERRL, EOMI, no papilledema
- Cranial Nerves: Mild decreased sensation in V2 distribution on right side, otherwise intact
- Motor: 5/5 strength throughout, no drift
- Sensory: Intact to light touch, pinprick, proprioception, and vibration
- Reflexes: 2+ and symmetric throughout
- Coordination: Finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin intact
- Gait: Normal, tandem gait intact

### IMAGING FINDINGS
MRI Brain with and without contrast (03/10/2018): 0.5 cm extra-axial dural-based lesion along the right frontal convexity with homogeneous enhancement. Findings consistent with a small WHO Grade I meningioma. No surrounding edema or mass effect on adjacent brain parenchyma.

### ASSESSMENT
40-year-old female with a newly diagnosed 0.5 cm right frontal convexity meningioma, likely WHO Grade I. The patient's symptoms may be partially related to the meningioma, though some symptoms may be attributable to her history of migraines. Given the small size of the lesion, lack of significant mass effect, and mild symptoms, conservative management is recommended at this time.

### PLAN
1. Conservative management with watchful waiting approach
2. Follow-up MRI in 6 months to assess for growth
3. Neurosurgery follow-up after repeat imaging
4. Continue current medications for diabetes and hypertension
5. Consider prophylactic migraine medication; referral to neurology
6. Patient education regarding symptoms that would warrant urgent evaluation
7. Karnofsky Performance Status (KPS): 90 (Able to carry on normal activity; minor symptoms)

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT (09/20/2018)

### INTERVAL HISTORY
Patient reports headache frequency has decreased to 1-2 times per week after starting topiramate 50mg daily as prescribed by neurology. Right-sided facial numbness persists but has not worsened. Dizziness with positional changes has improved. She continues to work as both a librarian and food critic but reports taking more frequent breaks while reading to help with concentration.

### PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Unchanged from previous examination. Mild decreased sensation in V2 distribution on right side.

### IMAGING FINDINGS
MRI Brain with and without contrast (09/15/2018): Stable 0.5 cm right frontal convexity meningioma without change in size or enhancement characteristics. No surrounding edema or mass effect.

### ASSESSMENT
Stable WHO Grade I right frontal convexity meningioma. Improved headache symptoms with topiramate, likely addressing the migraine component of her symptoms.

### PLAN
1. Continue conservative management with watchful waiting
2. Next MRI in 12 months given stability
3. Continue topiramate as prescribed by neurology
4. Recommend ergonomic assessment of workstation at library
5. Follow up in 12 months after next MRI
6. KPS: 90 (Able to carry on normal activity; minor symptoms)

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT (10/05/2019)

### INTERVAL HISTORY
Patient reports stable symptoms over the past year. Headaches well-controlled on topiramate. Right-sided facial numbness unchanged. No recurrence of visual symptoms. She notes improved concentration after workplace ergonomic adjustments. Patient reports her diabetes is well-controlled with current medication regimen.

### PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Unchanged from previous examinations.

### IMAGING FINDINGS
MRI Brain with and without contrast (09/25/2019): Stable 0.5 cm right frontal convexity meningioma without change in size or enhancement. No surrounding edema or mass effect.

### ASSESSMENT
Stable WHO Grade I right frontal convexity meningioma after approximately 18 months of observation. Patient's symptoms are well-controlled with current management.

### PLAN
1. Continue conservative management
2. Next MRI in 12 months
3. Continue current medications
4. Discuss stress management techniques given dual occupation demands
5. Follow up in 12 months after next MRI
6. KPS: 95 (Normal activity with minor symptoms)

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT (10/10/2020)

Patient reports slight increase in headache frequency over the past 3 months (now 2-3 times per week), which she attributes to increased work stress as her food critic blog has gained popularity. Facial numbness remains stable. She denies any new neurological symptoms. Her diabetes control has worsened slightly with HbA1c increasing from 6.8% to 7.3%.

### PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Unchanged from previous examinations.

### IMAGING FINDINGS
MRI Brain with and without contrast (10/02/2020): Right frontal convexity meningioma now measures 0.6 cm, representing a slight increase from previous studies. No surrounding edema or significant mass effect.

### ASSESSMENT
WHO Grade I right frontal convexity meningioma with minimal growth over 2 years of observation. Slight worsening of headache symptoms possibly related to stress rather than tumor growth given the minimal change in size.

### PLAN

### ASSESSMENT

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT (11/18/2022)

### INTERVAL HISTORY
Patient reports increased headache frequency and intensity over the past month. She also notes worsening right-sided facial numbness and occasional right-sided facial twitching. She reports increased stress at work due to library budget cuts and potential job insecurity. She has had difficulty maintaining her blood glucose levels with more frequent hyperglycemic episodes.

Vital signs stable. Neurological examination shows increased sensory deficit in V2 distribution on right side. New finding of mild right facial asymmetry with slight weakness of right nasolabial fold.

MRI Brain with and without contrast (11/10/2022): Right frontal convexity meningioma now measures 0.9 cm, showing continued growth. Minimal surrounding edema now visible. No significant mass effect on adjacent brain parenchyma.

WHO Grade I right frontal convexity meningioma with accelerated growth over the past 6 months and development of minimal surrounding edema. Patient's symptoms have worsened, possibly related to tumor growth and/or increased stress.

3. Continue current medications without steroids
4. Gradual return to full-time work as symptoms allow
5. Follow up in 3 months after next MRI
6. KPS: 80 (Normal activity with effort; some symptoms)

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT (11/03/2023)

### INTERVAL HISTORY
Patient reports continued improvement in symptoms. Headaches now occur 1-2 times weekly with reduced intensity. Right-sided facial numbness further improved. Tinnitus has resolved. She has returned to full-time work at the library and occasional food critic activities. Diabetes well-controlled with current regimen.

### PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Vital signs stable. Mild sensory deficit in right V2 distribution. No facial weakness. Neurological examination otherwise normal.

### IMAGING FINDINGS
MRI Brain with and without contrast (10/28/2023): Right frontal convexity meningioma measures 1.0 cm, showing slight decrease in size. Surrounding edema has largely resolved. No mass effect on adjacent brain parenchyma.

### ASSESSMENT
WHO Grade I right frontal convexity meningioma, status post stereotactic radiosurgery with good response. Decreasing tumor size and resolution of peritumoral edema. Significant improvement in clinical symptoms.

### PLAN
1. Continue post-radiosurgery monitoring
2. Next MRI in 6 months
3. Continue current medications
4. Resume normal activities as tolerated
5. Follow up in 6 months after next MRI
6. KPS: 90 (Able to carry on normal activity; minor symptoms)

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT (05/15/2024)

### INTERVAL HISTORY
Patient reports stable and minimal symptoms over the past 6 months. Headaches occur approximately once weekly and respond well to over-the-counter medication. Right-sided facial numbness is barely noticeable. She has resumed full-time work at the library and regular food critic activities. Diabetes remains well-controlled.

### PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
Vital signs stable. Very mild sensory deficit in right V2 distribution. Neurological examination otherwise normal.

### IMAGING FINDINGS
MRI Brain with and without contrast (05/08/2024): Right frontal convexity meningioma measures 0.8 cm, showing continued decrease in size. No surrounding edema. No mass effect.

### ASSESSMENT
WHO Grade I right frontal convexity meningioma, status post stereotactic radiosurgery with excellent response. Continued decrease in tumor size with resolution of symptoms.

### PLAN
1. Continue post-radiosurgery monitoring
2. Next MRI in 12 months given favorable response
3. Continue current medications
4. No activity restrictions
5. Annual follow-up
6. KPS: 95 (Normal activity with minor symptoms)

---

## SUMMARY OF MANAGEMENT COURSE

This 40-year-old female with type 2 diabetes was initially diagnosed with a 0.5 cm right frontal convexity WHO Grade I meningioma in March 2018. Given the small size and minimal symptoms, a conservative watchful waiting approach was initially adopted with regular MRI surveillance.

Over the following years, the meningioma demonstrated slow but progressive growth, eventually reaching 1.1 cm by May 2023. During this period, the patient's symptoms gradually worsened, particularly headaches and right-sided facial numbness, with eventual development of new neurological symptoms including facial weakness, tinnitus, and a brief episode of speech difficulty.

After approximately 5 years of conservative management, the decision was made to proceed with stereotactic radiosurgery due to tumor growth, increasing peritumoral edema, and worsening symptoms affecting quality of life. Following radiosurgery in June 2023, the patient demonstrated excellent response with tumor shrinkage, resolution of edema, and significant improvement in symptoms.

The patient's KPS score fluctuated throughout her course, ranging from a low of 70 during the period of most severe symptoms to a high of 95 following successful treatment. Her occupations as both a librarian and food critic influenced management decisions, particularly regarding work modifications during symptomatic periods and considerations for medical leave.

The patient's case demonstrates the value of initial conservative management for small, minimally symptomatic meningiomas, with appropriate transition to intervention when clinically indicated. Regular imaging surveillance, symptom monitoring, and consideration of quality of life factors were essential components of her care.

**Current KPS: 95** (Normal activity with minor symptoms)

clinical_notes.aggressive:
# NEUROSURGICAL CLINICAL NOTES

## PATIENT INFORMATION
- **Patient:** 62-year-old female
- **Blood Type:** O+
- **Occupation:** Researcher
- **MRN:** 72849365
- **Allergies:** None known

---

## INITIAL CONSULTATION - 06/12/2014

### CHIEF COMPLAINT
Progressive headaches over 3 months, worse in the morning and with position changes; right-sided weakness and numbness in the leg; difficulty with fine motor tasks in right hand; occasional episodes of confusion; urinary incontinence; difficulty concentrating on research tasks.

### HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Patient is a 62-year-old female researcher who presents with a 3-month history of progressive headaches that are worse in the morning and exacerbated by positional changes. She reports right-sided weakness and numbness in the leg that has been worsening over the past month, along with difficulty performing fine motor tasks with her right hand. Patient also notes occasional episodes of confusion that have interfered with her ability to perform complex research analysis. Recently developed urinary incontinence. Patient reports these symptoms have significantly impacted her work performance.

### PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
- Hypertension controlled with lisinopril 10mg daily
- History of migraine headaches that have changed in character recently
- Surgical menopause at age 48 following hysterectomy for fibroids
- Osteoporosis diagnosed 2 years ago, on alendronate
- Family history of breast cancer in mother
- No prior neurological disorders
- No history of radiation exposure
- No prior malignancies

### PHYSICAL EXAMINATION
- **Vital Signs:** BP 138/82, HR 76, RR 16, Temp 36.7°C, O2 Sat 98% on RA
- **General:** Alert, oriented to person, place, and time
- **HEENT:** PERRL, EOMI, no papilledema
- **Neurological:** Right-sided lower extremity strength 4/5, decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick in right leg. Right hand grip strength 4/5 with mild difficulty with rapid alternating movements. Reflexes 3+ in right lower extremity, 2+ elsewhere.
- **Gait:** Mild circumduction of right leg with ambulation

### DIAGNOSTIC STUDIES
**MRI Brain with and without contrast (06/10/2014):**
- 4.1 cm parasagittal/falx meningioma in the left frontoparietal region
- Significant mass effect on the left motor and sensory cortex with 5mm midline shift
- Moderate surrounding edema
- Homogeneous enhancement with dural tail sign
- No evidence of brain invasion

### ASSESSMENT
62-year-old female researcher with a large 4.1 cm parasagittal/falx meningioma causing significant mass effect and neurological symptoms including right-sided weakness, sensory changes, and signs of increased intracranial pressure.

Preliminary WHO Grade I meningioma based on imaging characteristics, though final grading will depend on histopathology.

### PLAN
1. **Recommend surgical intervention within 2 weeks** given the size, location, and symptomatic nature of the tumor
2. **Surgical approach:** Left frontoparietal craniotomy for complete tumor resection (Simpson Grade I-II)
3. **Pre-operative optimization:**
   - Dexamethasone 4mg q6h to reduce peritumoral edema
   - Levetiracetam 500mg BID for seizure prophylaxis
4. **Functional MRI and DTI tractography** to map motor and sensory pathways
5. **Schedule neurocognitive testing** to establish baseline
6. **Discuss occupational impact:** Recommend medical leave from research activities for at least 6 weeks post-surgery
7. **KPS score:** 70 (Cares for self but unable to carry on normal activity or do active work)

---

## SURGICAL NOTE - 06/26/2014

### PROCEDURE
Left frontoparietal craniotomy for resection of parasagittal/falx meningioma

### FINDINGS
- 4.1 cm well-circumscribed, firm, highly vascular parasagittal meningioma with dural attachment
- Tumor compressing but not invading the superior sagittal sinus
- No evidence of brain invasion
- Simpson Grade II resection achieved (complete tumor removal with coagulation of dural attachment)

### SURGICAL DETAILS
Under general anesthesia, a left frontoparietal craniotomy was performed. Neuronavigation was utilized for precise localization. The tumor was identified and carefully dissected from surrounding brain tissue. Several feeding vessels from the middle meningeal artery were identified and coagulated. The tumor was removed in a piecemeal fashion with careful attention to preserve the superior sagittal sinus. The dural attachment was extensively coagulated. Intraoperative motor and sensory evoked potential monitoring showed improvement in signal after tumor decompression. Estimated blood loss was 350cc. Patient tolerated the procedure well.

### PATHOLOGY (PRELIMINARY)
WHO Grade I Meningioma, meningothelial subtype

### POSTOPERATIVE PLAN
1. ICU monitoring for 24 hours
2. Continuation of dexamethasone with taper over 7 days
3. Levetiracetam 500mg BID for 1 month
4. Physical therapy consultation for right-sided weakness
5. Post-operative MRI at 24-48 hours
6. Follow-up in clinic in 2 weeks

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 07/10/2014 (2 WEEKS POST-OP)

### SUBJECTIVE
Patient reports improvement in headaches but continues to have mild right leg weakness and occasional difficulty with fine motor tasks in the right hand. No new seizures or confusion episodes. Reports fatigue with daily activities.

### OBJECTIVE
- **Vital Signs:** BP 132/78, HR 72, RR 16
- **Neurological:** Right leg strength improved to 4+/5, right hand grip 4+/5, improved coordination
- **Surgical site:** Well-healed incision without signs of infection

### IMAGING
**Post-operative MRI (06/28/2014):**
- Near-complete resection of the parasagittal meningioma
- Minimal residual enhancement along the falx
- Resolving edema and decreased midline shift to 2mm

### FINAL PATHOLOGY
WHO Grade I Meningioma, meningothelial subtype
- Ki-67 proliferation index: 3%
- No brain invasion
- Progesterone receptor positive

### ASSESSMENT
Status post Simpson Grade II resection of WHO Grade I parasagittal meningioma with good recovery and improving neurological function.

### PLAN
1. Continue physical therapy for right-sided weakness
2. Occupational therapy for fine motor skills
3. Taper dexamethasone over next 7 days
4. Continue levetiracetam for 2 more weeks then discontinue if no seizures
5. Recommend gradual return to work with modified duties at 4 weeks post-op
6. Follow-up MRI in 3 months
7. Next clinic visit in 1 month
8. **KPS score:** 80 (Normal activity with effort, some signs of disease)

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 10/15/2014 (3.5 MONTHS POST-OP)

### SUBJECTIVE
Patient reports significant improvement in right-sided weakness. Occasional mild headaches. Has returned to research work but notes some difficulty with sustained concentration. No seizures or confusion episodes.

### OBJECTIVE
- **Neurological:** Right leg strength 5/5, right hand grip 5/5, normal gait
- **Cognitive:** Intact memory, attention slightly reduced from baseline

### IMAGING
**MRI Brain (10/10/2014):**
- No evidence of tumor recurrence
- Small area of enhancement at resection site likely representing post-surgical change
- Complete resolution of edema and mass effect

### ASSESSMENT
Excellent post-operative recovery with resolution of neurological deficits. No evidence of tumor recurrence.

### PLAN
1. MRI surveillance every 6 months for 2 years, then annually if stable
2. Discontinue physical therapy
3. Cognitive rehabilitation to address concentration issues
4. Return to full work duties with recommendation for regular breaks
5. Follow-up in 6 months with repeat MRI
6. **KPS score:** 90 (Able to carry on normal activity, minor symptoms of disease)

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 04/22/2015 (10 MONTHS POST-OP)

### SUBJECTIVE
Patient reports doing well with near-complete resolution of symptoms. Occasional mild headaches that respond to OTC analgesics. Has resumed full research duties without significant limitations.

### OBJECTIVE
- **Neurological:** Normal strength and sensation throughout
- **Cognitive:** Improved concentration and cognitive function

### IMAGING
**MRI Brain (04/18/2015):**
- No evidence of tumor recurrence
- Stable post-surgical changes

### ASSESSMENT
Continued excellent recovery with no evidence of tumor recurrence.

### PLAN
1. Continue surveillance MRI every 6 months
2. Follow-up in 6 months
3. **KPS score:** 100 (Normal, no complaints, no evidence of disease)

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 10/28/2015 (16 MONTHS POST-OP)

### SUBJECTIVE
Patient reports new onset of intermittent headaches over the past month, different from her previous migraines. No neurological deficits or visual changes.

### OBJECTIVE
- **Neurological:** Normal strength and sensation throughout
- **Cognitive:** Normal cognitive function

### IMAGING
**MRI Brain (10/25/2015):**
- 1.2 cm recurrent enhancing lesion at the original resection site along the falx
- No significant mass effect or edema

### ASSESSMENT
Early recurrence of meningioma at the original resection site. Given the relatively quick recurrence, there is concern for a potentially more aggressive tumor biology than initially suggested by the WHO Grade I pathology.

### PLAN
1. Recommend early re-intervention with surgical resection given the patient's occupation requiring high cognitive function and the concerning pattern of early recurrence
2. Schedule repeat craniotomy within 4 weeks
3. Consider adjuvant radiation therapy post-operatively regardless of pathology
4. Repeat pre-operative workup including functional MRI
5. **KPS score:** 90 (Able to carry on normal activity, minor symptoms of disease)

---

## SURGICAL NOTE - 11/23/2015

### PROCEDURE
Left frontoparietal re-craniotomy for recurrent parasagittal/falx meningioma

### FINDINGS
- 1.2 cm recurrent meningioma at previous resection site
- Tumor firmly adherent to falx cerebri
- No obvious invasion of superior sagittal sinus
- Simpson Grade II resection achieved

### SURGICAL DETAILS
Re-craniotomy performed through previous incision. Dense adhesions encountered and carefully dissected. Recurrent tumor identified and removed completely. Dural attachment coagulated extensively. Estimated blood loss 200cc.

### PATHOLOGY (PRELIMINARY)
WHO Grade II Atypical Meningioma

### POSTOPERATIVE PLAN
1. ICU monitoring for 24 hours
2. Dexamethasone with taper over 5 days
3. Levetiracetam for seizure prophylaxis
4. Post-operative MRI at 24-48 hours
5. Plan for adjuvant radiation therapy given atypical histology
6. Follow-up in clinic in 2 weeks

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 12/07/2015 (2 WEEKS POST SECOND SURGERY)

### SUBJECTIVE
Patient reports mild headaches and fatigue. No new neurological symptoms.

### OBJECTIVE
- **Vital Signs:** BP 136/82, HR 74, RR 16
- **Neurological:** Normal strength and sensation throughout
- **Surgical site:** Well-healed incision

### IMAGING
**Post-operative MRI (11/25/2015):**
- Complete resection of the recurrent tumor
- No evidence of residual enhancement
- Minimal post-operative changes

### FINAL PATHOLOGY
WHO Grade II Atypical Meningioma
- Increased cellularity and nuclear atypia
- 4 mitoses per 10 high-power fields
- Ki-67 proliferation index: 8%
- Brain invasion: Absent
- Progesterone receptor: Weakly positive

### ASSESSMENT
Status post Simpson Grade II resection of recurrent WHO Grade II atypical meningioma. The upgraded histological diagnosis explains the early recurrence and necessitates more aggressive management.

### PLAN
1. Refer to radiation oncology for adjuvant radiotherapy to begin within 4-6 weeks
2. Recommended dose: 54 Gy in 30 fractions
3. More intensive follow-up with MRI every 3 months for the first year
4. Consider extended leave from work during radiation therapy
5. Follow-up in 1 month
6. **KPS score:** 80 (Normal activity with effort, some signs of disease)

---

## RADIATION ONCOLOGY CONSULTATION - 12/21/2015

### ASSESSMENT
62-year-old female with recurrent WHO Grade II atypical parasagittal/falx meningioma status post two resections.

### PLAN
1. Fractionated external beam radiation therapy: 54 Gy in 30 fractions
2. Treatment to begin 01/11/2016
3. Target volume to include tumor bed plus 1-2 cm margin
4. Six-week course of treatment
5. Weekly on-treatment visits to monitor side effects

---

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 03/15/2016 (POST-RADIATION THERAPY)

### SUBJECTIVE
Patient reports fatigue and mild alopecia following completion of radiation therapy. Occasional headaches. Reports difficulty returning to full research duties due to fatigue.

### OBJECTIVE
- **Neurological:** Normal strength and sensation
- **Skin:** Mild radiation dermatitis in the treatment field

### IMAGING
**MRI Brain (03/10/2016):**
- No evidence of tumor recurrence

Status post Simpson Grade II resection of WHO Grade II atypical meningioma with completed course of adjuvant radiation therapy. Experiencing expected radiation-related side effects.

### PLAN

3. Gradual return to work with modified schedule

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 06/20/2016 (7 MONTHS POST SECOND SURGERY)

Patient reports improvement in fatigue. Hair regrowth beginning. No headaches or new neurological symptoms. Has returned to part-time research work.

- **Neurological:** Normal strength and sensation

Continued good recovery following surgery and radiation therapy for WHO Grade II atypical meningioma.

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 09/22/2016 (10 MONTHS POST SECOND SURGERY)

Patient reports doing well with continued improvement in energy levels. No new neurological symptoms. Has resumed full research duties.

### OBJECTIVE
- **Neurological:** Normal strength and sensation
- **Cognitive:** Normal cognitive function

### IMAGING
**MRI Brain (09/18/2016):**
- No evidence of tumor recurrence

Excellent recovery with no evidence of tumor recurrence.

3. **KPS score:** 90 (Able to carry on normal activity, minor symptoms of disease)

## FOLLOW-UP VISIT - 12/15/2016 (13 MONTHS POST SECOND SURGERY)

Patient reports continued good health. No headaches or neurological symptoms.

- **Neurological:** Normal examination

**MRI Brain (12/10/2016):**

Small recurrence of atypical meningioma adjacent to the superior sagittal sinus. Given the location and small size, stereotactic radiosurgery is recommended over repeat surgical resection.
